ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SAFETY EQUIPMENT FOR WORKERS
(Legislation for compulsory use to minimise industrial accidents)


    1. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Labour if he will introduce legislation to make it compulsory for workers to use the necessary safety equipment in the course of employment, so as to minimise industrial accidents.

Column: 370



    The Minister for Labour (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Govindasamy, Sir, it is not necessary to introduce further legislation to make it compulsory for workers to use the necessary safety equipment in the course of their employment so as to minimise industrial accidents, because such a provision is already contained in section 69 of the Factories Act which stipulates as follows:

    `No person employed in a factory or in any other place to which any provisions of this Act apply shall wilfully interfere with or misuse any means, appliance, convenience or other thing provided in pursuance of this Act for securing the health, safety or welfare of the persons employed in the factory or place, and where any means or appliance for securing health or safety is provided for the use of any such person under this Act, he shall use the means or appliance.'

    Anyone who contravenes section 69 of the Act shall be liable to a fine not exceeding $500 or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or to both such penalties. Although vested with the powers of prosecution under section 69 of the Act, the Ministry has yet to invoke this section against any workers for two reasons. Firstly, the Factory Inspectorate of the Ministry was until recently understaffed, and strict enforcement of the Act was therefore not possible.

    The second, and more important, reason is that it is better to inculcate in the workers a sense of safety consciousness through education and persuasion. Towards this end, appeals have been made both inside and outside Parliament to employers and employees to observe strictly various safety rules and regulations.

Column: 371



    The Factory Inspectorate, through its newsletters, has been harping on the tune that it is only through the concerted efforts of the workers, the employers and the Government that we can hope to cut down the rate of industrial accidents. The National Trades Union Congress, the National Safety First Council and other organisations have also supported this call. However, these appeals have apparently achieved very little or no result, as the number of industrial accidents due to the irresponsibility of the employers and the negligence of the workers has not shown any sign of a decrease.

    Consequently, my Ministry will commence action to prosecute both employers and employees if they contravene the provisions of the Factories Act or any regulations made thereunder. I would like to enlist the support of every Member of this House when we take this stern but necessary action so as to protect the welfare, health and safety of the workers.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): May I ask the Minister how many Factory Inspectors have been recruited this year? Also, how do they go about inspecting the factories in order to understand the conditions and the safety arrangements therein?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Govindasamy, Sir, I have not got the figures with me, but I should think that roughly a dozen new Factory Inspectors have been employed this year. Many of them have, in fact, been appointed only recently and they are still undergoing training. So their effectiveness will not be as expected. But, nevertheless, they are making their rounds now, and when we commence action against the employers and the employees, I am quite sure there will be some effect on the rate of industrial accidents.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Will the Minister see to it that only approved types of safety equipment are

Column: 372

issued and at the expense of the employers? This should be made compulsory.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: We do advise employers that all safety equipment should, as far as possible, be of the type recommended or tested by the Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research. I think it is only reasonable that the employers should provide safety equipment to the workers free of charge.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Can the Minister point out to me which part of the Factories Act makes it compulsory for employers to issue safety equipment, other than the Building Operations and Works of Engineering Construction Regulations of 1970? If the employers will not issue it, how can the workers use it?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Where the employers have failed to provide the safety equipment, then they will be prosecuted, not the workers. But where the employers have provided the safety equipment but, for some reason or another, the workers have refused to use it, then the workers will be penalised.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: The Factories Act does not say what industry or what occupation except-

    Mr N. Govindasamy: We have 26 Questions today. Perhaps the Member can submit another Question later on for answer.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: I think it is of the utmost importance that this question be answered.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: The last question then.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: I think, for a start, we will probably begin with the building industry and also industries like ship-repairing where the workers will be working under hazardous and dangerous conditions.

Column: 373

TRAFALGAR ESTATE
(Development plans)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Communications what plans his Ministry has to develop Trafalgar Estate which formerly housed the Trafalgar Receiving Station; and whether the residents, who have been living in the Estate for many years, will be given Temporary Occupation Licences to continue to live there and to enjoy the amenities such as water and electricity and better roads.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Govindasamy, Sir, Trafalgar Station used to be a high frequency radio receiving station. As such, it was sensitive to electrical interference. Thus it was necessary to impose conditions on the distribution of electricity supplies when the Station was functioning. However, the radio services operating from this Station have since 1st June, 1971, been transferred to operate from our Yio Chu Kang Station. There is, therefore, no necessity now to place any restriction on the provision of amenities such as the public utilities and better roads to the present residents.

    As my Ministry has yet no plans for the Trafalgar site, the residents who have been living there for many years may remain on Temporary Occupation Licences until the site is required for development.

COMPULSORY PRIMARY
EDUCATION
(Introduction of legislation)


    3. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Education if he will consider introducing legislation to make primary education compulsory for children who are citizens and resident in Singapore and have attained the age of six years.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Govindasamy, our records show that more than 97 per cent of the children who are citizens and resident in Singapore and who have attained the age of six years on 1st January each year attend either Government or

Column: 374

Government-aided schools. There is, therefore, no need to introduce legislation to make primary education compulsory.

Column: 374

JURONG TOWN
(Building of secondary school and expansion of existing primary school)


    4. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Education (a) if a secondary school will be built in Jurong Town, and when; and (b) whether the existing primary school in Jurong Town will be expanded to cope with the pressing demand.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the Ministry of Finance has been asked to provide Jurong with a secondary school.

    There is, of course, only one primary school in Jurong and this is not big enough to accommodate all the primary pupils living there. As an emergency measure to solve the demand for school places in 1972, the Jurong Town Primary School will be expanded by the addition of six prefabricated classrooms to be undertaken by the School Advisory Committee with funds provided by the Committee and the School Fund Income Account.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): May I ask when a secondary school will be built in Jurong Town? The Minister has not replied to this question yet.

    Mr Lim Kim San: We have asked the Ministry of Finance to provide Jurong with a secondary school. As to when this will be completed, it will depend very much upon how soon the money will be made available.

Column: 374

PRIVATE EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS
(Regulations to protect students' interests)


    5. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Education whether there are adequate regulations governing the conduct of private, commercially-run educational institutions, to ensure that the interests of their students are fully protected.

Column: 375



    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the Education Act, 1970, and the School Regulations, 1957, contain adequate provisions for regulating the conduct of private commercial educational institutions to ensure that the interests of their students are protected. These regulations provide, inter alia, that no private school shall operate until it is registered and registration is granted only when the syllabuses, the qualifications of teachers and the rates of fees have been approved, and the health and safety regulations have been complied with. However, in the past, some private school operators circumvented the regulations by registering their school as a business with the Registrar of Business Names and commenced operations without applying for registration as a school. Arrangements have been made with the Registrar of Business Names not to register any private school as a business until it has been registered as a school.

    It is also true, Sir, that in the past some unscrupulous private school operators have exploited unsuspecting students eager to acquire certain skills. A case in point was the Academy of Technical Studies in Thomson Road which closed down after a brief spell of operation when the principal absconded with the fees collected from the students. The supervisor of the school has agreed to make full restitution of the fees collected and the police are still inquiring into the matter.

    My Ministry will in future exercise tighter control in processing applications for registration of private schools to ensure that only bona fide schools will be registered. Any private school violating the Education Act and the Schools Regulations will be deregistered and, if necessary, its sponsors will be prosecuted.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE SCHEME

    6. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Social Affairs if he will consider an upward revision of the

PEDESTRIAN CROSSINGS AT UPPER PAYA LEBAR ROAD
(Commencement and completion dates of construction)


    7. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development if tenders for the construction of the two pedestrian crossings at Upper Paya Lebar Road have been awarded, and when the construction is expected to commence and to be completed.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Sir, I am pleased to inform the Member that the construction of an overhead pedestrian bridge for Upper Paya Lebar Road near Elling South School has commenced and is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

    Consideration will be given to the provision of another crossing, possibly a push-button light-controlled pedestrian crossing, across Upper Paya Lebar Road after the road-widening works which are now being done are completed.

Column: 376

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE AT
SERANGOON ROAD/BOON KENG ROAD
(Construction)


    8. Inche Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether a pedestrian overhead bridge will be constructed at the

Column: 377

junction of Serangoon Road and Boon Keng Road to span both those roads, and when.

    Mr Barker: Sir, there are no plans to construct a pedestrian overhead bridge at the junction of Serangoon and Boon Keng Roads to span both or either of these roads.

    Inche Abdul Aziz Karim: Sir, I thought it was approved in 1969 that a pedestrian overhead bridge would be constructed at the junction of Boon Keng Road and Serangoon Road. Can the Minister explain why there cannot be an overhead bridge at the junction of these two roads?

    Mr Barker: Sir, at present there is one light-controlled surface crossing across Serangoon Road near its junction with Towner Road and Boon Keng Road. That portion of Serangoon Road which is now two-way will be turned into a one-way street when its extension to Bendemeer Road is completed early next year, whereupon Bendemeer Road itself will also be made one-way. Boon Keng Road will then be turned into a two-way traffic system to allow cars to turn from Serangoon Road to Bendemeer Road and from Bendemeer Road to Serangoon Road. When this new traffic circulatory system is introduced, another light-controlled surface crossing will be installed across Boon Keng Road near its junction with Serangoon Road.

PEDESTRIAN OVERHEAD BRIDGE
ACROSS JALAN TOA PAYOH
(Construction)


    9. Dr Augustine H. H. Tan asked the Minister for Law and National Development, in view of (i) the development of Jalan Toa Payoh as part of the Pan-Island Expressway and the consequent hazards to pedestrians, especially children, crossing the road, and (ii) the likely benefits to hawkers at the new hawkers' centre being built at Jalan Tenteram, if his Ministry has plans to build a pedestrian overhead bridge over Jalan Toa Payoh to be sited next to the new hawkers' centre.

Column: 378



    Mr Barker: Sir, the Public Works Department has a proposal to construct a pedestrian overhead bridge across Jalan Toa Payoh near its junction with Kim Keat Road not only to serve pedestrians and school children, but also the hawkers' centre in the area. The bridge will be included in next year's programme and, if all goes well, it is expected to be completed by October next year.

    10. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider replacing zebra crossings, wherever possible, with light-controlled pedestrian crossings.

HIGHWAYS


    11. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will consider replacing the present street lighting along main roads and highways with yellow street lighting.

As considerable funds are needed, the programme has to be carried out in stages. Some heavy traffic intersections, arterial roads and highways already have yellow street lighting.

TOA PAYOH CENTRAL TERMINUS
(Provision of toilet facilities and bus shelters)


    12. Mr Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Law and National Development if there are any plans to provide toilet facilities and bus shelters for commuters and bus workers at the Toa Payoh Central terminus.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Sir, toilet facilities to cater for passengers using the bus terminus at the Toa Payoh Town centre will be provided in the hawkers' centre adjacent to the bus terminus as well as at the entrance to the bus terminus at Lorong 2, Toa Payoh. Construction of the toilet facilities is in progress and is expected to be completed by February next year.

    With regard to the bus shelters, quotations are being called for the construction of four large circular-shaped fibreglass shelters at the terminus. These bus shelters are expected to be built by the middle of next year.

(Sale of flats in Temple Estate)

TOA PAYOH ESTATE
(Building of more hawkers' centres)


    14. Mr Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether the Housing and Development

Column: 380

Board has any plans to build more hawkers' centres in Toa Payoh Estate to accommodate the large number of unauthorised hawkers plying in the Estate.

    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Sir, a hawkers' centre and a market are under construction at the Toa Payoh Town centre. There will be 33 footstalls in the hawkers' centre and about 55 footstalls and 219 other stalls in the market.

    Another hawkers' centre is also being planned in Neighbourhood I to the north of Lorong 7, Toa Payoh. This hawkers' centre will have about 80 footstalls and about 150 other stalls.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD
(Eviction of tenants breaching Board's regulations)


    15. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) whether it is the policy of the Housing and Development Board to evict a tenant it a member of his household is convicted of an offence which, if committed by the tenant, would constitute a breach of the Board's regulations; and (b) whether, if such a policy exists, it could be rescinded or be appropriately altered.

    Mr Barker: Sir, it is generally the policy of the Housing and Development Board to evict a tenant if a member of his household is convicted of an offence which, if committed by the tenant, would result in the tenant's eviction. However, eviction is only imposed if the offence is a serious one, e.g., where the flat is used illegally as a common gaming house, a brothel or a den in which opium or ganja is smoked or other drugs are used or kept, or where the tenant or a member of his household assaults an official of the Board. In most of these cases, the tenant cannot surely disclaim liability altogether. It is therefore not thought desirable to rescind or alter a policy which is imposed for the protection of the majority of tenants.

(Committee to consider evictions of tenants and review of appeals)


    16. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether, in view of the Housing and Development Board's near monopoly of cheap housing in Singapore and the very grave housing difficulty which may face a person evicted from a Board flat, he will consider setting up a special committee, composed not only of officials and / or members of the Board but also of members of the public, to consider cases of proposed evictions and to review appeals against such evictions.

    Mr Barker: Sir, exceptional cases of hardship suffered by those evicted from Housing Board flats are referred for consideration to the Allocations Committee of the Board under the chairmanship of Mr P. Govindaswamy, Member of Parliament for Anson, who also heads the Public Inquiries and Complaints Bureau in the Ministry. Appeals by those evicted or otherwise aggrieved and not satisfied are also made from time to time direct to the Ministry.

    In view of the facilities already existing for appeals by those aggrieved, it is considered not yet necessary to set up another body for the purpose.

MONOSODIUM GLUTAMATE
(Banning of use in baby-food preparations)


    17. Dr Augustine H. H. Tan asked the Minister for Health, in view of the possible brain-damage to babies, if his Ministry will consider banning the use of monosodium glutamate in baby-food preparations.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Sir, the Member for Whampoa might have based his suggestion that monosodium glutamate should be banned from baby-food preparations on a report by a Dr J. W. Olney, an Assistant Professor of Psychiatry at Washington University in St. Louis, that infant mice injected under the skin with

Column: 382

large amounts of monosodium glutamate or MSG developed brain damage.

    I would like to explain here that Dr Olney's conclusion was challenged by Mr Oser, a biochemist, who is also a member of the United States National Academy of Science Committee on Food Protection. Mr Oser claimed that Dr Olney's observations did not have any relevance to the question of the safety of MSG as a food seasoning agent largely because the MSG was injected under the skin of mice. The critical experiments, he said, should involve feeding MSG orally to the animals. Dr Olney's experiments had also been done by using doses far in excess of what has been normally used.

    An Expert Committee jointly formed by the Food and Agriculture Organisation and the World Health Organisation on Food Additives was, however, not able to evaluate the evidence and come to specific conclusions in 1970. The report, which appeared in the W.H.O. Technical Report, Series No. 445 at page 20, paragraph 3.4 is as follows:

    `Glutamic acid is a normal constituent of dietary proteins and also occurs freely in many natural foods. It is itself used as a condiment and is an important constituent of other condiments (e.g. soy sauce). The present state of knowledge concerning monosodium glutamate was reviewed. Although attention has recently been drawn to adverse acute effects from ingestion of foods high in free glutamate content the Committee considers that it is unable to advise any restriction on use at the present time. It was considered that self-limitation of intake of foods containing glutamate by susceptible individuals would be possible. Since there is a considerable amount of work in progress the Committee postponed evaluations of this compound as a food additive until the results of the current work are available.'

    The Expert Committee reported a year later, in 1971, that although the weight of evidence does not support the contention that monosodium glutamate as an additive in the diet can lead to brain damage in humans, caution is desirable. The food manufacturers, however, have decided to play it safe. In 1969, the manufacturers of baby foods in North America imposed a voluntary ban on it and British firms followed later.

Column: 383



    Since these countries are the main sources of baby foods imported into Singapore, it would not be necessary to take any other action with regard to banning of this additive in baby foods in Singapore.

    Further, if we are to ban the use of monosodium glutamate in baby food preparations, the relevant question that will arise will be how effective it will be in actual practice. Can we, for instance, control its use in food preparations at home which may be given to children and babies? Another relevant question is that if it has ill effects on the brain of humans, which is questionable, why should the restriction of its use be limited to baby foods only, since the human brain is known to continue development right up to full maturity, which is at the age of 20 to 25 years? Thus, for the move of banning it to be logical and effective in practice, you must ban it completely, that is, by banning its importation and manufacture, which clearly does not merit it in this case.

    However, in order to be on the cautious side, all our Maternal and Child Health Clinics have been instructed to warn mothers against the excessive use of monosodium glutamate as well as to actively discourage them from using it at all when preparing baby foods.

Column: 383

HAWKER INSPECTORS
(Seizure of goods of hawkers who have committed offences)


    18. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Health if he will consider the issue of instructions to Hawker Inspectors not to take away the goods, etc., of hawkers to whom they have issued notices of offence for causing obstruction.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Govindasamy, Sir, the seizure of goods of hawkers who have committed offences is only resorted to in cases where they belong to incorrigible hawkers who choose persistently to flout the law.

    In normal circumstances, the Hawker Inspectorate only issue notices to

Column: 384

offenders for committing an offence under the hawkers' law.

    The law provides for seizure of goods in addition to a fine, for certain good reasons, for example, to prevent hawkers selling at unspecified sites and prohibited areas which invariably are areas which have been cleared of hawkers. It would be extremely unfair to the hawkers who had vacated the cleared areas if the authorities were to allow new or other hawkers to occupy the places they had vacated. Thus, in fairness, there should be very much heavier penalties, including the seizure of goods, for hawkers who persistently flout the law by hawking in cleared and prohibited areas.
